title: Hats off to Mr White Hat
text:
“And the prize for outstanding contribution to network security goes to . . . Mr White Hat”

The hacker who stole more than $600m in cryptocurrencies this month continued to earn plaudits from his victim on Tuesday, as Poly Network mounted a charm offensive to recover the $235m in crypto assets he is still holding.

Poly called on Mr White Hat to transfer the “keys” — or alphanumeric strings — to the account holding the other tokens “as soon as possible”. It offered a handful of sweeteners, including the opportunity for the hacker to become its chief security adviser and renewed an offer to provide a bounty totalling half a million dollars.

The hacker has claimed to be an ethical attacker — a so-called “white hat” who looks for weaknesses in computer networks to improve them, rather than being motivated by money. In case you missed it, read our weekend account of this crypto caper.

“We are grateful for Mr White Hat's outstanding contribution to Poly Network's security enhancements,” Poly said on Tuesday. The decentralised finance (DeFi) project now has control back of about $330m of the stolen assets, while stablecoin operator Tether has frozen $33m worth pending a legal process.

Meanwhile, wireless operator T-Mobile has confirmed personal information of almost 50m current and former customers has been “stolen” in what it described as a “highly sophisticated cyber attack” on its systems.

“Unauthorised individuals” accessed data including names, birth dates, social security numbers and drivers' licence information on 7.8m existing customers and more than 40m former or prospective customers, the carrier said.

The Internet of (Five) Things

1. Google's new AI search tool
Google recently flipped the switch on a powerful new search tool — a large-scale AI model known as MUM that can act like a virtual research assistant as it sifts the web for solutions to complex questions. But, as Richard Waters reports, critics warn it could “internalise” search traffic and keep internet users locked in a Google universe.

2. Netflix's fresh European challengers
Comcast and ViacomCBS have joined forces to take on Netflix and other streaming services in several European countries, with plans to launch a new video on-demand platform on the continent. The subscription service, to be named SkyShowtime, will unite content from the US companies' brands including Paramount, Universal and Nickelodeon.

3. Tencent bucks crackdown
Tencent warned investors that more regulatory changes would impact China's tech sector, as it reported a jump in second-quarter profits, bucking expectations that the social media, gaming and fintech group would already be damaged by the moves. Net profit rose 29 per cent year on year to Rmb42.6bn ($6.6bn), well ahead of analysts' estimates of about Rmb34bn.

4. Covid and lack of chips cripple manufacturing
Covid-19 is disrupting plans by Apple, Google, Amazon and others to shift production from China to Vietnam, according to this exclusive in Nikkei Asia reported by today's #techAsia newsletter. Meanwhile, China's largest private carmaker Geely Auto is the latest industry player to warn of continued “uncertainty” around production because of chip supply shortages. Kathrin Hille comments for Global Insight that only Huawei is suffering among Chinese tech companies from the US barring access to semiconductors. 

5. Remittance fintechs herald payments revolution 
Fintech start-ups are finally getting traction in their mission to disrupt banking. Remittances, smaller cross-border payments between individuals, have been an excellent entry point, according to our Big Read. Anne Richards, Fidelity International CEO, comments monetary transmission mechanisms may be further compressed. Sign up to our #fintechFT newsletter for the industry latest.

Tech tools — Realme's suitcase smartphones

Realme unveiled two new smartphones today and its first laptop, all at competitive prices.  The design of its GT Master Edition and GT Explorer Master Edition has been inspired by . . . suitcases. Their backs are “engraved to reflect a suitcase's undulating grille, being the first concave vegan-leather design in smartphone history,” it says. There is a 120Hz Samsung AMOLED screen and a Dolby Atmos Dual Speaker, along with an impressive array of cameras and accompanying software. The phones start at $399, with a UK launch also planned. The realme Book is a 14in Windows laptop with an Intel Core i5 processor and up to 11 hours of battery life. It has the same slim and light profile as a MacBook Air and starts at $749.
